Award.AwardTitle: IBSS-Ex: Integrating Social Science and Systems Methodologies for Sustainability: Promoting Appropriate Waste-Disposal Practices in Low-Income Neighborhoods

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will explore the potential for a new approach to reduce trash accumulation and promote recycling in low-income urban neighborhoods. The project will demonstrate how different social science methods can be integrated to provide insights and answers useful in urban sustainability management. The investigators will bring together perspectives and approaches from behavioral science, decision and management sciences; econometrics and behavioral economics; and the social determinants of health. The project will provide new insights regarding the factors that influence waste-creation and -disposal practices, and it will assess the potential for different kinds of approaches to reduce litter, increase recycling, and improve urban environmental characteristics. The project will be conducted in low-income neighborhoods in the city of Baltimore, but it will provide new theoretical insights in a diverse range of other locales, and it will inform the development of programs and policies designed to promote urban neighborhood quality and sustainability. The investigators will work in collaboration with neighborhood residents, community associations, environmental organizations and city agencies to investigate the causes and to pilot test and evaluate solutions to the problem of urban trash accumulation. The project will provide valuable education and training opportunities for graduate students, and it will involve students from a number of high schools that have science programs with a health focus and with large numbers of students underrepresented in science and engineering in the U.S.

This project will build on a pilot study conducted in early 2014 that identified four key factors contributing to the accumulation of solid waste in neighborhoods: (1) high turnover of tenants in rental properties; (2) landlords who do not provide trash containers, information about trash collection procedures, or access to the back alley to tenants; (3) difficulties faced by sanitation code enforcement officials given current laws; and (4) drug dealers and users who encourage trash accumulation because it helps conceal their activities from law enforcement officials. The investigators will integrate empirical and theoretical modeling methods from different social science fields to assess social and physical factors influencing waste creation and disposal practices and create measurement tools for evaluation of factors affecting waste creation and disposal. They will develop and test intervention packages designed to improve household and community waste management, and they will employ a systems-analysis approach for the evaluation of strategies. Four types of empirical analyses will inform the parameterization of the socio-physical decision sciences model. The first will be analyses of historical data for broad relationships between waste policies and the amounts of waste and litter. These data will provide a useful baseline and insights on correlations with policies but will not provide the fine-grained resolution needed for models of relationships between influences and choices. The second and third types will be laboratory experiments and field studies to generate individual and household-level data under more controlled conditions to identify relationships that are more causal in nature. The fourth will be questionnaire studies addressing attitudes towards proper and improper disposal methods, which will help identify which interventions will be received most positively by the public under given circumstances, with an emphasis placed on design features that can make a large difference in intervention effectiveness. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A stroll down a city street inevitably exposes the observer to litter. Litter in American cities primarily stems from inadequate packaging and handling of trash that is put out for pick-up by householders, and careless discarding of trash and waste.  In urban settings, such as Baltimore City, trash and litter accumulation pose important environmental, social, and health problems. Trash impacts the health and wellbeing of residents. Children living in neighborhoods with poor physical characteristics – including litter and garbage on streets and sidewalks – are more likely to suffer from anxiety and depression. Rodent infestation, linked to littering and dumping, can infest homes, contributing to increased asthma. Finally, trash and litter can contribute to low perceptions of safety, and contribute to a more favorable environment for crime.

One challenge in confronting this problem is to know what combination of actions will be most effective. We could try out different combinations, and learn through trial and error what works best. However, this is costly in terms of time, effort and funding. An alternative is to create a model containing elements in the larger system that result in accumulation of trash and litter in cities. We can use such a systems model to predict what combinations of actions would work best. We created a systems model for urban Baltimore. We incorporated data available from the local government, as well as data we had collected in neighborhoods. The model indicated that the greatest potential for change would be with an intervention that works to change social norms related to littering, and at the same time puts in place financial incentives to not litter.

We conducted in-depth interviews and observations of community meetings and the neighborhood. Interviewees described frequent moves among renters, vacant and abandoned homes, poor cohesion between neighbors in some neighborhoods, and lack of enforcement of bylaws related to waste disposal as barriers to correct waste disposal by householders. Solutions they suggested included provision of better waste receptacles (recently adopted by the City of Baltimore), educational materials, and information about when, where and how waste collection occurs.  We did not find that the root of the problem is ignorance and lack of awareness, as is commonly supposed. A web of interrelated factors creates an environment favoring waste accumulation.

 

The City of Baltimore conducted a city-wide free distribution of new, larger, trash bins during the second year of this study. To complement this intervention, the study team worked with the Patterson Park Neighbors’ Association (PPNA) to produce a Clean City Guide, Fridge magnets, and Flyers. The clean city guide contains detailed information about trash reduction efforts such as the trash schedule, materials that can be recycled and information on means to contact the city for assistance. The Clean City Guide was printed in both English and Spanish, and targets an audience already engaged in efforts to reduce trash accumulation. The magnets and flyers contain basic trash and recycling information, cues to action such as trash schedule, and positive neighborhood social norms messaging.  They were designed in collaboration with the Patterson Park Neighborhood Greening Partnership and the Healthy Harbor Initiative. The intervention materials reminded people of days and times for pickup of trash and recycling, gave instructions on how to dispose of bulk trash and how to handle rat infestation, and gave other helpful ways to reduce the overall trash burden.

 During 2016-2017 we completed the distribution of the magnets to the intervention streets. We have maintained our partnership with the Patterson Park Neighborhood Greening Partnership. As a part of this relationship we attended monthly community meetings to keep them up to date on our research project and plans for data collection. These complementary materials were distributed in half the blocks in the study neighborhood, so that we could look at their impact on trash accumulation.
